HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 28, 1928

GROUP PICTURES
ON SALE AT BARN
All group pictures for this
year's Hullabaloo have been
completed and are now on sale
at the Barn. They are on exhibition in the downstairs
lunchroom.
Fraternity pictures have
been completed and will be distributed this week. Some of
them have already been,given
out.
The Hullabaloo also wishes
to announce that there are positions open on the busine,,
staff to any freshmen who
can print signs.

NEW JAY TO
APPEAR MARCH 4
Donald White, editor-inchief of the Black and Blue
Jay, has announced that the
new "Jay" is scheduled to
make its appearance about
March 4. The cover for this
issue is by Kolb and very attractively portrays the theme
of the "Wanderlust Number."
Little delay has been experienced in gathering the material, and the old bird is expected to appear on schedule.

It has always been maintained
that one of the great benefits to be
derived from college life is the
opportunity which is afforded to the
individual to make social contacts
with his fellow-students and to thus
lay the foundation for life-long
friendships. To further this end,
and to give a tangible basis on which
to build, Greek letter fraternities
were formed, and very shortly* all
the so-called desirable men in many
universities were swearing eternal
fealty to some vague ideas, brotherhood and some people whom they
had known for a week at least.

he makes no attempt to meet and
associate with other'classmates, and
when—and even this happens only
in rare cases—he becomes aware of
his mistake some tithe during his
third year of his residence in college, it is too late; his habits have
grown so that he finds it impossible
to shake off the shackles that have
grown up during the preceding
years. So he is thrown back once
been cast in the same mold as himself, and sinks once more in the
identical rut. There lies the catastrophe!

As one looks at this situation in
its present state at Johns Hopkins,
the conclusion is forced -upon one
that the whole business has missed
fire. Instead of paving the way for
the close interweaving of human
lives, which is friendship at its best,
it has had precisely the opposite
effect.

"The Devil's Disciple"
PETTY LARCENY

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW'S
Melodramatic Comedy of The American Revolution

It is becoming an annual necessity to call the attention of the
student body to the fact that books on the reserve shelves in the
library have a status different from that of other books. Many
students persistently refuse to recognize the unfortunate situation
where classes are composed of more than one individual, and
where, consequently, certain books have to be set aside for use
only at certain times. They don't seem to realize, moreover, that
the- chief reason why books are placed upon reserve shelves is to
save the expense of requiring each student to buy the text himself.
It is the grossest kind of selfishness to make away with a reserve
book at nine in the morning in order to read it at three in the
afternoon, or to take it at noon and keep it overnight. There is no
way for the librarians to act as policemen to prevent these practices; the only remedy is for the offenders to exercise a little more
unselfishness than is usually their wont.
The library itself can alleviate the situation considerably, also.
if it would purchase two or three copies of the texts that it knows
are used every year. The small extra expense would, we believe.
be more than justified.

A squadron of five airplanes was
assembled the other day to transport the basketball team of the University of Wichita when they played
Hay's State Teachers' College on
the latter's court. So far as is
known this is the first time any athletic team has enjoyed such a novel
method of transportation. This
step was considered necessary, because, although Hay's is only two
hundred miles from Wichita, the
train connection is so poor that it is
Otherwise a two days' trip between
the two institutions.
* * * * *
Athletic officials at Ohio. State
University frankly term intercollegiate athletic radio broadcasting as
a "necessary evil." They believe
that while the broadcasting of athletic contests is one way of losing
sPectators, it is also the only in cans
of keeping alumni and friends of the
University interested in sports. Consequently, Ohio State continues
broadcasting at a cost of about one
hundred dollars per gain e. * * * * *
Coeds of Midland College are
offered their college letter-. upon
taking an athletic pledge for two
Weeks and by exhibiting moderate
ability in one sport. The joker in
the plan which the young ladies have
already drawn is that 10.30 is placed
as curfew hour for six nights a
week and 11.30 the. other. This appears quite a task for modern femininity. We would say that if a coed
can do this she ably deserves her reWard.
* * * * *
The student governMent Council
at Amherst College recently handed
in their resignation as a body. The
reason assigned was because of the
Practice of the institution to employ
a watchman as a spy while an honor
system was supposedly functioning.
* * * * *
The gentlemanly undergraduates
of Furman University do not prefer
blondes. .There are exactly 155 who
state openly that they prefer those
enticing bits of feminity whose hair
is of a darker hue, while only 95
boast adherence to the famous tenet
of Anita Loos. These figures were
Procured by the business staff of the
student paper at that institution for
exactly what purpose we confess We
do not know. Several days were
Spent in securing attestations, and
the sheet finally provided an interesting study in chirography. This
was displayed after completion in
the lobby of a local theater where
the townsfolk were enabled to secure
a glimpse of several hundred absolutely bona fide collegiate signatures.
* * * * *
The Association for the Advancement of Atheism recently received a
rebuff at the hands of authorities of
the University of Pennsylvania. The
Association had requested the privilege of presenting its views to the
undergraduates. The faculty, however, contended that only instructive
criticisms should be offered the student body and tendered their refusal to the organization on the
grounds that it had nothing constructive to offer.
* * * * *
Dr. Samuel Williams, a graduate
of Ohio Wesleyan in the class of
1848 and until recently the oldest
living college graduate in the. United
States, died in Cincinnati last week
at more than a hundred years of age.
* * * * *

who make use of the nighttime for
their activity. Although the Goucherites have no rifle team to our
knowledge, they possess a marksManship rivaled by none — qu'en

Prahl and Berry Find Stage
Facilities Inadequate
NEW
MAY GO NEXT YEAR
Club May Visit Eastern Shore
Next Season
There \Xi11 be no Eastern Shore
trip for the Barnstormers Club this
year, according to Douglas Prahl,
business manager of the club. The
news comes as rather contrary to
what has been expected, since former reports on the trip were favorable.
The reasons for not sending the
club on a trip are several in number, the main one being that stage
facilities are very poor. In order
to arrange for a trip, Douglas Prahl
and George Berry journeyed to the
Eastern Shore early last Wednesday morning and returned Thursday after having visited Salisbury
and Easton. A large number of
people were interviewed with reference to bringing the production to
their town, but difficulties were encountered which could not be overcome.

"Lucky Strikes Never Affect Our Wind"
say Moss and Fontana
International Dancers stress
importance of wind condition

"In our work as international dancers
we have discovered a wonderful new
point about Lucky Strikes of which we
are very happy to tell you. As can
readily be realized, wind and physical
condition are of the utmost importance
to ballroom dancers. Our work is hard
and taxes the wind to the utmost. We
both have smoked Lucky Strikes for a
number of years and can safely say that
these cigarettes in addition to furnishing
US much pleasure in our hours of relaxation, have never affected our wind
or physical fitness in any way."
ckoc.s

Stage Facilities Poor

"Stage facilities were very bad,"
said Prahl. "The stages were so
small that it would be ,necessary to
cut the sets down tremendously. Another difficulty we encountered was
in getting a booking on a week end:
neither of the two available theatres in Salisbury and Easton would
give us anything except a mid-week
date, and that fact would prohibit
the trip, because of the number of
classes which would have to be cut."
Another difficulty which arose
was the fact that the fast approaching Lenten season would be the only
time in which the production could
be put, on and the• Eastern Shore
people would probably not give particularly good patronage during that
time. The people who were interviewed on the matter seemed very
desirous of having Hopkins present
such a show, hut the concurrence of
numerous difficulties makes it practically impossible.
Plans for Next Year

However, plans are being made
for the club to make the trip next
year, since it is felt that if sufficient
time were allowed in advance the
project would be very successful.
Cambridge was suggested as a possibility, but after extensive inquiry
in Salisbury it was found that it
would be extremely difficult to arrange any kind of suitable backing
in the former city.
The Easter holidays were suggested as a possible time for the
trip, but as there are a number of
men taking Geology I, the annual
expedition under Dr. Schwartz
would eliminate that period.
"We had a very enjoyable trip,"
Prahl stated. "The people were
very nice to us and gave us lots of
help and information. The club
will probably make a trip to the
Eastern Shore next year."

I sure get some riled when I see
where some fellow is crowing over
the fact that being older, and having
run into Edgeworth sooner than his
less fortunate compatriots, he challenges the world as the champion
long-time member of the Edgeworth
Club.
He doesn't deserve any medals.
He got his reward in the enjoyment
of his smoking for the added number of years. He was just lucky in
starting sooner, that's all.
However, if you care to delve into
ancient history, look up when they
first started to pull down the old
Grand Central Station in New
York,* then add at least six months
to that, and you will arrive at the
approximate time when I first joined
the club.
I have smoked at least One pipeful of every other tobacco I have
seen advertised, sometimes through
'
necessity, but most of the time to
prove to myself that I have been
right in sticking to the old blue tin.
Yours truly,
H. M. Wittridge.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1928

SEALED IN
CAMPAIGN FOR NEW ASHES OF DR. REMSEN
WALL OF CHEMISTRY BUILDING
BUILDING STARTS
Campaigners Hold Banquet at
Southern Hotel
COMMITTEE FORMED
John R. Sherwood to Lead Drive
For Levering Hall Funds
Definite organization to raise the
amount necessary for the new Levering Hall got under way last
Thursday night at a dinner given
at the Emerson Hotel for the division managers and team captains.
Dinner was served at 6.15 and business was undertaken at 7.00. John
R. Sherwood, general chairman of
the campaign and former Student
Council president at Hopkins, made
a brief speech giving a resume of
the program and the plan to be
followed.
New Building Needed

Commemorating the untiring intereSt of Dr. Ira Remsen in connection with the University, a sealed
urn containing the ashes of that professor has been inclosed in walls of
the newly-named Remsen Hall.
Over the inclosed urn a bronze memorial tablet has been placed by the
University.
Dr. Rensen's remains were
brought to Baltimore in accordance
with the wishes of Mrs. Remsen.
He died on March 4 of last year in
Carmel, Cal., and the body was cremated.
The memorial has been placed in
the wall at the head of the stairway
leading up from the first floor at the
east end of the building. The building has recently been renamed by
order of the Board of Trustees, and
is now known as Remsen Hall.

On the bronze tablet, directly
under which is the sealed urn, is
inscribed the following:
Behind This Tablet Repose the
Ashes of
Dr. Ira Remsen
1846-1927
Professor of Chemistry, 1876-1901
President, 1901-1913
In order to further commemorate
the work of Dr. Remsen, a meeting
was held in the C. E. Building Sunday, at which President Goodnow
presided.
Other speakers who were present
were Dr. Charles H. Hirty, president of the Synthetic Organic
Chemical Manufacturers' Association; Morris Whitridge of Baltimore; and Dr. William H. Howell,
director of the Johns Hopkins
School of Hygiene and Public
Health.

It has always been maintained
that one of the great benefits to be
derived from college life is the
opportunity which is afforded to the
individual to make social contacts
with his fellow-students and to thus
lay the foundation for life-long
friendships. To further this end,
and to give a tangible basis on which
to build, Greek letter fraternities
were formed, and very shortly* all
the so-called desirable men in many
universities were swearing eternal
fealty to some vague ideas, brotherhood and some people whom they
had known for a week at least.

when—and even this happens only
in rare cases—he becomes aware of
his mistake some tithe during his
third year of his residence in college, it is too late; his habits have
grown so that he finds it impossible
to shake off the shackles that have
grown up during the preceding
years. So he is thrown back once
been cast in the same mold as himself, and sinks once more in the
identical rut. There lies the catastrophe!

As one looks at this situation in
its present state at Johns Hopkins,
the conclusion is forced -upon one
that the whole business has missed
fire. Instead of paving the way for
the close interweaving of human
lives, which is friendship at its best,
it has had precisely the opposite
effect.

BOOKS

"The Devil's Disciple"
PETTY LARCENY

GEORGE BERNARD SHAW'S
Melodramatic Comedy of The American Revolution

It is becoming an annual necessity to call the attention of the
student body to the fact that books on the reserve shelves in the
library have a status different from that of other books. Many
students persistently refuse to recognize the unfortunate situation
where classes are composed of more than one individual, and
where, consequently, certain books have to be set aside for use
only at certain times. They don't seem to realize, moreover, that
the- chief reason why books are placed upon reserve shelves is to
save the expense of requiring each student to buy the text himself.
It is the grossest kind of selfishness to make away with a reserve
book at nine in the morning in order to read it at three in the
afternoon, or to take it at noon and keep it overnight. There is no
way for the librarians to act as policemen to prevent these practices; the only remedy is for the offenders to exercise a little more
unselfishness than is usually their wont.
The library itself can alleviate the situation considerably, also.
if it would purchase two or three copies of the texts that it knows
are used every year. The small extra expense would, we believe.
be more than justified.

A squadron of five airplanes was
assembled the other day to transport the basketball team of the University of Wichita when they played
Hay's State Teachers' College on
the latter's court. So far as is
known this is the first time any athletic team has enjoyed such a novel
method of transportation. This
step was considered necessary, because, although Hay's is only two
hundred miles from Wichita, the
train connection is so poor that it is
Otherwise a two days' trip between
the two institutions.
* * * * *
Athletic officials at Ohio. State
University frankly term intercollegiate athletic radio broadcasting as
a "necessary evil." They believe
that while the broadcasting of athletic contests is one way of losing
sPectators, it is also the only in cans
of keeping alumni and friends of the
University interested in sports. Consequently, Ohio State continues
broadcasting at a cost of about one
hundred dollars per gain e. * * * * *
Coeds of Midland College are
offered their college letter-. upon
taking an athletic pledge for two
Weeks and by exhibiting moderate
ability in one sport. The joker in
the plan which the young ladies have
already drawn is that 10.30 is placed
as curfew hour for six nights a
week and 11.30 the. other. This appears quite a task for modern femininity. We would say that if a coed
can do this she ably deserves her reWard.
* * * * *
The student governMent Council
at Amherst College recently handed
in their resignation as a body. The
reason assigned was because of the
Practice of the institution to employ
a watchman as a spy while an honor
system was supposedly functioning.
* * * * *
The gentlemanly undergraduates
of Furman University do not prefer
blondes. .There are exactly 155 who
state openly that they prefer those
enticing bits of feminity whose hair
is of a darker hue, while only 95
boast adherence to the famous tenet
of Anita Loos. These figures were
Procured by the business staff of the
student paper at that institution for
exactly what purpose we confess We
do not know. Several days were
Spent in securing attestations, and
the sheet finally provided an interesting study in chirography. This
was displayed after completion in
the lobby of a local theater where
the townsfolk were enabled to secure
a glimpse of several hundred absolutely bona fide collegiate signatures.
* * * * *
The Association for the Advancement of Atheism recently received a
rebuff at the hands of authorities of
the University of Pennsylvania. The
Association had requested the privilege of presenting its views to the
undergraduates. The faculty, however, contended that only instructive
criticisms should be offered the student body and tendered their refusal to the organization on the
grounds that it had nothing constructive to offer.
* * * * *
Dr. Samuel Williams, a graduate
of Ohio Wesleyan in the class of
1848 and until recently the oldest
living college graduate in the. United
States, died in Cincinnati last week
at more than a hundred years of age.
* * * * *

who make use of the nighttime for
their activity. Although the Goucherites have no rifle team to our
knowledge, they possess a marksManship rivaled by none — qu'en

Prahl and Berry Find Stage
Facilities Inadequate
NEW
MAY GO NEXT YEAR
Club May Visit Eastern Shore
Next Season
There \Xi11 be no Eastern Shore
trip for the Barnstormers Club this
year, according to Douglas Prahl,
business manager of the club. The
news comes as rather contrary to
what has been expected, since former reports on the trip were favorable.
The reasons for not sending the
club on a trip are several in number, the main one being that stage
facilities are very poor. In order
to arrange for a trip, Douglas Prahl
and George Berry journeyed to the
Eastern Shore early last Wednesday morning and returned Thursday after having visited Salisbury
and Easton. A large number of
people were interviewed with reference to bringing the production to
their town, but difficulties were encountered which could not be overcome.

"Lucky Strikes Never Affect Our Wind"
say Moss and Fontana
International Dancers stress
importance of wind condition

"In our work as international dancers
we have discovered a wonderful new
point about Lucky Strikes of which we
are very happy to tell you. As can
readily be realized, wind and physical
condition are of the utmost importance
to ballroom dancers. Our work is hard
and taxes the wind to the utmost. We
both have smoked Lucky Strikes for a
number of years and can safely say that
these cigarettes in addition to furnishing
US much pleasure in our hours of relaxation, have never affected our wind
or physical fitness in any way."
ckoc.s

Stage Facilities Poor

"Stage facilities were very bad,"
said Prahl. "The stages were so
small that it would be ,necessary to
cut the sets down tremendously. Another difficulty we encountered was
in getting a booking on a week end:
neither of the two available theatres in Salisbury and Easton would
give us anything except a mid-week
date, and that fact would prohibit
the trip, because of the number of
classes which would have to be cut."
Another difficulty which arose
was the fact that the fast approaching Lenten season would be the only
time in which the production could
be put, on and the• Eastern Shore
people would probably not give particularly good patronage during that
time. The people who were interviewed on the matter seemed very
desirous of having Hopkins present
such a show, hut the concurrence of
numerous difficulties makes it practically impossible.
Plans for Next Year

However, plans are being made
for the club to make the trip next
year, since it is felt that if sufficient
time were allowed in advance the
project would be very successful.
Cambridge was suggested as a possibility, but after extensive inquiry
in Salisbury it was found that it
would be extremely difficult to arrange any kind of suitable backing
in the former city.
The Easter holidays were suggested as a possible time for the
trip, but as there are a number of
men taking Geology I, the annual
expedition under Dr. Schwartz
would eliminate that period.
"We had a very enjoyable trip,"
Prahl stated. "The people were
very nice to us and gave us lots of
help and information. The club
will probably make a trip to the
Eastern Shore next year."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1928

SEALED IN
CAMPAIGN FOR NEW ASHES OF DR. REMSEN
WALL OF CHEMISTRY BUILDING
BUILDING STARTS
Campaigners Hold Banquet at
Southern Hotel
COMMITTEE FORMED
John R. Sherwood to Lead Drive
For Levering Hall Funds
Definite organization to raise the
amount necessary for the new Levering Hall got under way last
Thursday night at a dinner given
at the Emerson Hotel for the division managers and team captains.
Dinner was served at 6.15 and business was undertaken at 7.00. John
R. Sherwood, general chairman of
the campaign and former Student
Council president at Hopkins, made
a brief speech giving a resume of
the program and the plan to be
followed.
New Building Needed

Commemorating the untiring intereSt of Dr. Ira Remsen in connection with the University, a sealed
urn containing the ashes of that professor has been inclosed in walls of
the newly-named Remsen Hall.
Over the inclosed urn a bronze memorial tablet has been placed by the
University.
Dr. Rensen's remains were
brought to Baltimore in accordance
with the wishes of Mrs. Remsen.
He died on March 4 of last year in
Carmel, Cal., and the body was cremated.
The memorial has been placed in
the wall at the head of the stairway
leading up from the first floor at the
east end of the building. The building has recently been renamed by
order of the Board of Trustees, and
is now known as Remsen Hall.

On the bronze tablet, directly
under which is the sealed urn, is
inscribed the following:
Behind This Tablet Repose the
Ashes of
Dr. Ira Remsen
1846-1927
Professor of Chemistry, 1876-1901
President, 1901-1913
In order to further commemorate
the work of Dr. Remsen, a meeting
was held in the C. E. Building Sunday, at which President Goodnow
presided.
Other speakers who were present
were Dr. Charles H. Hirty, president of the Synthetic Organic
Chemical Manufacturers' Association; Morris Whitridge of Baltimore; and Dr. William H. Howell,
director of the Johns Hopkins
School of Hygiene and Public
Health.
